items.text: When I see an opportunity for reward, I feel a surge of energy that propels me to act immediately.
items.rationale: Captures the core BAS feature of approach motivation and energization in response to reward cues.

items.text: I get really excited when I'm working toward something I want.
items.rationale: Reflects goal-directed positive affect and drive, central to BAS functioning.

items.text: I tend to act on impulse when something appealing presents itself.
items.rationale: Impulsive approach behavior toward appetitive stimuli is a hallmark of high BAS sensitivity.

items.text: I'm the kind of person who goes after what they want without hesitation.
items.rationale: Describes strong approach motivation and low hesitancy, core BAS characteristics.

items.text: The possibility of getting a reward motivates me more than the fear of losing something.
items.rationale: Directly contrasts reward sensitivity (BAS) with punishment sensitivity (BIS), anchoring clearly on BAS.

items.text: When good things happen, I feel intense joy and want to seek out even more positive experiences.
items.rationale: Reward responsiveness and positive affect amplification are key BAS components.

items.text: I often find myself pursuing new goals before I've finished old ones because something exciting catches my attention.
items.rationale: Reflects BAS-driven fun-seeking and impulsive shifting toward novel reward cues.

items.text: People describe me as someone who is always chasing the next big thing.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of persistent approach motivation and novelty-seeking, characteristic of high BAS.

items.text: I feel most alive when I'm actively working toward a goal that excites me.
items.rationale: Links positive arousal and vitality to goal pursuit, a defining feature of BAS activation.

items.text: If there's a chance to win, I'll take the risk even if the odds aren't great.
items.rationale: Risk-taking in pursuit of reward reflects strong BAS drive overriding cautious evaluation.

items.text: I have a hard time resisting temptation when something pleasurable is available.
items.rationale: Difficulty inhibiting approach toward appetitive stimuli is a core BAS-related behavior.

items.text: Thinking about the things I want in life fills me with motivation and determination.
items.rationale: Anticipatory positive affect and drive toward desired outcomes are central BAS processes.

items.text: I sometimes get so caught up in the excitement of a new venture that I overlook potential downsides.
items.rationale: Primarily reflects BAS-driven enthusiasm, but the overlooking of downsides could also suggest low BIS sensitivity.

items.text: I'm naturally drawn to competitive situations where there's something to be gained.
items.rationale: Approach toward competitive reward is BAS-related, but competitiveness could also involve Fight system activation.

items.text: When I feel frustrated about not getting what I want, I push harder and sometimes get aggressive about it.
items.rationale: Frustrated approach motivation is BAS-related, but the aggressive response overlaps with the Fight-Flight-Freeze System's fight component.

items.text: I frequently worry about things that might go wrong, even when everything seems fine.
items.rationale: Chronic worry and threat anticipation in ambiguous situations are hallmark BIS processes.

items.text: When I'm unsure about the outcome of a situation, I tend to hold back and wait.
items.rationale: Behavioral inhibition under uncertainty is the defining function of the BIS.

items.text: I spend a lot of time weighing the pros and cons before making a decision.
items.rationale: Cautious deliberation and conflict resolution processing are core BIS functions.

items.text: I often feel anxious when I can't predict what's going to happen next.
items.rationale: Anxiety triggered by uncertainty and unpredictability is a primary BIS output.

items.text: Even small signs that something could go wrong make me feel uneasy and cautious.
items.rationale: Heightened sensitivity to potential threat cues and resulting caution reflect strong BIS activation.

items.text: I tend to overthink situations, looking for hidden problems or risks.
items.rationale: Rumination and risk scanning are cognitive manifestations of BIS-driven vigilance.

items.text: I find it difficult to relax when there's an unresolved issue hanging over me.
items.rationale: Persistent arousal and inability to disengage from goal-conflict reflect ongoing BIS activation.

items.text: People tell me I'm too cautious and that I miss out on opportunities because of it.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of excessive caution and avoidance of uncertain opportunities, classic high BIS profile.

items.text: When I notice a conflict between what I want and what might happen, I freeze up and can't decide.
items.rationale: Goal-conflict detection leading to behavioral arrest and indecision is the core BIS mechanism.

items.text: I'm very sensitive to any sign of disapproval or criticism from others.
items.rationale: Sensitivity to social punishment cues reflects BIS-mediated vigilance to negative outcomes.

items.text: I often second-guess myself after making a decision, wondering if I chose wrong.
items.rationale: Post-decisional rumination and doubt reflect continued BIS conflict-monitoring activity.

items.text: I prefer to stick with what I know rather than try something new and uncertain.
items.rationale: Preference for familiarity over novelty under uncertainty is a behavioral consequence of high BIS sensitivity.

items.text: When facing a difficult choice, I sometimes feel physically tense and my mind races with worst-case scenarios.
items.rationale: Physical tension and catastrophizing are BIS-related, though intense physical symptoms could overlap with FFFS panic responses.

items.text: I avoid situations where I might be judged or evaluated by others.
items.rationale: Social avoidance driven by anticipated negative evaluation is BIS-related, but active avoidance behavior could also reflect FFFS flight responses.

items.text: When I sense danger in a social situation, I immediately want to leave the room.
items.rationale: The social threat detection is BIS-like, but the immediate escape urge is more characteristic of the FFFS flight response.

items.text: When I feel physically threatened, my first instinct is to get away as fast as possible.
items.rationale: Immediate flight response to proximal physical threat is a core FFFS output.

items.text: In a dangerous situation, I sometimes find myself completely unable to move or think clearly.
items.rationale: Freeze response—behavioral and cognitive paralysis under acute threat—is a defining FFFS reaction.

items.text: If someone physically confronts me, I instinctively fight back without thinking.
items.rationale: Reflexive aggressive defense in response to direct confrontation is the fight component of FFFS.

items.text: I experience sudden surges of panic that seem to come out of nowhere.
items.rationale: Panic attacks and acute fear responses are mediated by the FFFS, particularly the periaqueductal gray pathway.

items.text: When startled, my heart races and my body tenses up before I even understand what happened.
items.rationale: Automatic physiological startle response reflects rapid FFFS activation prior to cognitive appraisal.

items.text: I have a strong urge to escape when I feel trapped or cornered.
items.rationale: Escape motivation triggered by entrapment is a classic FFFS flight response.

items.text: In moments of extreme stress, I've noticed my body takes over and I react before I can think.
items.rationale: Automatic, pre-cognitive defensive reactions under acute stress are characteristic FFFS outputs.

items.text: I become intensely angry and reactive when I feel my safety is being threatened.
items.rationale: Defensive rage in response to perceived threat to safety is the fight component of FFFS.

items.text: I've had experiences where fear was so overwhelming that I felt detached from my own body.
items.rationale: Dissociative responses under extreme fear reflect the tonic immobility/freeze aspect of FFFS.

items.text: Loud, unexpected noises make me jump and feel immediately on edge.
items.rationale: Exaggerated startle reflex and subsequent hyperarousal are direct FFFS-mediated responses.

items.text: When I see someone in immediate physical danger, my body reacts before my mind catches up.
items.rationale: Rapid, automatic defensive mobilization in response to proximal threat cues is a core FFFS function.

items.text: I tend to lash out verbally or physically when I feel backed into a corner with no way out.
items.rationale: Defensive aggression when escape is blocked represents the shift from flight to fight within the FFFS.

items.text: I sometimes feel a rush of adrenaline in stressful situations that makes me want to either run or confront the problem head-on.
items.rationale: Describes FFFS arousal and fight-or-flight readiness, though 'confront the problem' could shade into BAS-driven active coping.

items.text: I avoid places where I've previously had a frightening experience.
items.rationale: Conditioned avoidance of fear-associated contexts is FFFS-related, but the anticipatory nature could also involve BIS anxiety processes.

items.text: I feel a nagging sense of dread when I think about situations that have scared me in the past.
items.rationale: Anticipatory dread about past threats involves FFFS fear memory, but the ruminative, anticipatory quality is more characteristic of BIS anxiety.

items.text: I find it easy to calm myself down after becoming upset or stressed.
items.rationale: Effective self-soothing and emotional recovery are core functions of the socioemotional regulation system.

items.text: Being around people I trust helps me feel safe and reduces my stress significantly.
items.rationale: Social buffering of stress through attachment relationships is a primary mechanism of the socioemotional regulation system.

items.text: I'm good at reading other people's emotions and responding in a way that helps them feel better.
items.rationale: Empathic attunement and co-regulation of others' emotions reflect strong socioemotional regulation capacity.

items.text: When I'm distressed, reaching out to someone I care about is usually the first thing I do.
items.rationale: Proximity-seeking under distress is a core attachment-based regulatory strategy within this system.

items.text: I can usually manage my emotional reactions so they don't overwhelm me or others.
items.rationale: Effective emotion modulation that considers both self and social impact reflects mature socioemotional regulation.

items.text: Close relationships are essential to my sense of well-being and emotional stability.
items.rationale: Dependence on social bonds for emotional equilibrium is a defining feature of the socioemotional regulation system.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of comfort and security when I'm with people who understand me.
items.rationale: Felt security derived from attuned social connections reflects the attachment component of socioemotional regulation.

items.text: After a conflict with someone, I actively try to repair the relationship and restore harmony.
items.rationale: Relationship repair and conflict resolution behaviors are key outputs of the socioemotional regulation system.

items.text: I'm able to step back from intense emotions and think about them before reacting.
items.rationale: Cognitive reappraisal and reflective functioning are higher-order socioemotional regulation strategies.

items.text: People often come to me when they need emotional support because I make them feel heard.
items.rationale: Third-person recognition of co-regulatory capacity and empathic listening reflects strong socioemotional regulation.

items.text: Physical affection from loved ones—like a hug—can instantly reduce my anxiety.
items.rationale: Tactile social contact as an anxiety-reduction mechanism is a fundamental socioemotional regulatory process linked to oxytocin pathways.

items.text: I've learned to use my relationships as a source of strength during difficult times rather than withdrawing.
items.rationale: Secure-base utilization and social approach under stress reflect adaptive socioemotional regulation.

items.text: I sometimes struggle to manage my emotions on my own, but I feel much better once I talk to someone about it.
items.rationale: Highlights social regulation dependence, which is core to this system, but the difficulty with self-regulation could suggest low individual regulatory capacity rather than high system engagement.

items.text: I tend to mirror the emotions of people around me, which sometimes makes it hard to separate my feelings from theirs.
items.rationale: Emotional contagion reflects socioemotional attunement, but poor self-other differentiation could indicate dysregulation rather than effective regulation.

items.text: I feel deeply unsettled and anxious when my closest relationships are unstable or uncertain.
items.rationale: Attachment-related distress under relational uncertainty is socioemotional in nature, but the anxiety and uncertainty sensitivity overlap substantially with BIS processes.
